content.description: Steep face climbing on edges and flakes to a roof about 3/4 of the way up. Listed in the Supertopo guide as 5.12b.
content.location: Starts to the right of Flu and pulls through the obvious roof.

content.description: First bolt is about 15ft up, but it is easy climbing on good holds. Great route with good movement all the way to the end.  Crux is near the end of the route.
content.location: Starts about 15ft down the hill from Leflie

content.description:
Start up the blocky lower section of easy climbing to reach the first bolt.  Laybacks, finger locks, cracks, sidepulls, and crimps with a couple of exciting moves lead you through the next three bolts and around the aerate to the last two bolts.

**Route is still a little dirty**
content.location: Once you come down the main trail to the main area.  Follow the trail to the right and the cliff will be in your view. Once you about reach the cliff, look for a trail on the right leading up to the wall.

content.description: Semi-classic thin Tahoe granite slab arete that will test your slab technique; sustained.
content.location: On north-facing/right-hand crag - a 5.7 lies just to the left. 6 routes from the left (starting from the 5.9 slab by the gully approach)

content.description:
This is the first route on the left of the steep part of the main Berkley Camp wall, to the left of Flu (5.11d) and the right of the 5.9 bolted slab climb.

Great route with bomber rock and great movement in a beautiful position. The first bolt is quite high, but the climbing is easy getting up to it.

Start by climbing up some ledges, then move left into a crack. An arete with great holds takes you to the top. Would make an excellent first lead.

A 3 bolt 5.9 variation splits off to the right near the top on thin crimps for a couple moves to bigger holds, and its own anchor with chains.
content.protection: bolts. two bolt anchor with chains
content.location: On the left side of the rock with Salt Water Flush

content.description:
Striking, blank-looking left arete/face - stick clip mandatory as the 1st bolt is very high.

Great movement on small but positive holds, climbs better (and I thought easier) than it looks.
content.location: Left-hand arete just to the right of Saltwater Flush (belay from same flat tier about 20 feet above the dirt).

content.description: Splits off from Mellow Arete and has 3 bolts all to itself. You'll have to make it through a crimpy traverse with a few delicate moves before you can grab some thank-you-god holds that'll take you to the anchors. Multiple crux betas go at about the same grade.
content.location: Shares the first three bolts with Mellow Arete, to the left of Salt Water Flush.

content.description: The first bolt is shared with the New Jersey Turn Pike.  At the first bolt head to your right up following the bolts over the budging face into the thin dihedral.  Finish on the same anchor as New Jersey Turn Pike.

Super route, sustained and varied. Maybe the best route on the Berkeley Camp wall.

Shares the start of New Jersey Turnpike.  Clip the first bolt,  then trend right to the roof, pull the roof to easier climbing above.
content.protection: 8 Draws (Two long draws, one for the clip before the roof and one for the roof). Shares anchor with Witch Doctor. Cold Shuts.
content.location: Second route from the right on the main wall of Berkeley Camp.  Look for a techie face capped off by a small roof.  Skip up the devious bottom and keep it together for the sustained last bit.

content.description: Quality warmup for the area. Climb a less than vertical face on mostly big holds, with a thin crux near the 3rd bolt.
content.protection: 5 bolts. Between the 1st and 2nd bolts there is a runout on 5.6 terrain. A fall from here would likely result in hitting the ground. I believe a small cam or a nut would protect this safely. Two bolt anchor shared with 5.11s to the right. No chains, bring long slings to TR. Easy to walk to/off top. I recommend a directional on the last bolt if toproping.
content.location: First route encountered when coming down the approach gully

content.description: Finally, a reason to bring a small rack to Berekely Camp! Start up the corner taking the large crack up to a good stance, starting trending left to clip the bolt and move up into the pod.  Follow the crack to the anchors.
content.protection: .3 to 3" single rack + 1 bolt,  Anchor: Two chains with carabiners.
content.location: Once you come down the main trail to the main area.  Follow the trail to the right and the cliff will be in your view. Once you about reach the cliff, look for a trail on the right leading up to the wall.

content.description:
This route features enjoyable movement and deserves more traffic.  Looks harder and dirtier than it climbs, and therefore seems to have an adventurous feel.

Climb up a series of laybacks, snag a rest, then tackle the thought-provoking bulge and mantle up to the chains.  Feet when you need 'em, good clipping positions, clean falls, and all-day shade make this route worth the walk.
content.location:
Starts with obvious jugs in a diagonal crack above a dead log.

You can easily see the shady wall to the south from any of the climbs on the main wall.  After hiking down the approach gully, turn right (instead of left) and hug the cliff band for ~50' before heading downhill.  Continue toward the wall down/cross-slope through some small pine saplings and big dead pines, then beeline for the wall.  Probably the easiest way, plus we didn't get blown up by any unexploded ordnance.
